text:
Lamproite distribution in the Ellendale Field is controlled by NW-trending faults and 
 EW-trending en echelon faults and shears in the Fitzroy Trough (Jaques et al., 1986).  
 Most intrusions exist on basement fault-blocks near NE-trending cross-faults oriented 
 perpendicular to the Oscar Range.  They exhibit an east-west elongation and/or alignment 
 Ellendale 17 (E17) lies 25 km north of the Ellendale Field at the base of the Napier 
 Range. It is the largest of a group of three lamproites separated from the main area of the 
 Ellendale Field and comprises a large (41.8 ha) irregularly shaped vent.  The lamproite 
 intrudes the mudstones and limestones of the Late Devonian to Early Carboniferous 
 Fairfield Group. E17 is concealed beneath several metres of calcrete overlain by three 
 2 PREVIOUS WORK 
 Previous work done on Ellendale 4 and 9 provides critical background information as a 
 comparison for similar analysis on Ellendale 17 rocks.  Initial work done on Ellendale 17 
 provides a basis for follow-on work by Conquest. 
 Within the Ellendale 4 and 9 Olivine Lamproite pipes various volcaniclastic and 
 magmatic units display wide variations in diamond abundance due to primary magmatic 
 processes, country-rock dilution and surface enrichment during weathering (Horn, 2002). 
 Emplacement of the volatile-rich magma in to water-saturated country-rock is interpreted 
 to  have  caused  disaggregation  of  sandstone  forming  quartz-rich  lamproite  lapilli-tuffs.  
 Xenocrysts sampled from these early magmas indicate a shallow spinel-lherzolite mantle.

22.text: ct/100t)  (Kimberley  Diamond  Company,  2004).    However,  on  average,  diamonds  from

23.text: Ellendale 9 are larger (0.23 ct per stone) compared to those from Ellendale 4 (0.12 ct per

24.text: stone).  In addition, Ellendale 9 contains significant numbers of yellow stones resulting in

25.text: a larger proportion of gem-quality stones and a higher price per carat (557.5 A$mill for

26.text: Ellendale 9 and 297 A$mill).  Ellendale 4 diamonds are typically irregular and deformed

27.text: having  a  characteristic  brown  colour  and  lower  value.    A  distinct  chemical  difference

28.text: between  Ellendale  9  and  Ellendale  4  is  in  the  very  low  TiO2 (0-1  wt.  %)  of  chromite

29.text: xenocryst cores. This is interpreted to reflect the absence of metasomatic activity within

30.text: the mantle that is destructive to diamond (Ramsay, 1992).

text:
On  average,  Ellendale  4  rocks  have  a  higher  grade  (9.4  ct/100t)  than  Ellendale  9  (6.2 
 ct/100t)  (Kimberley  Diamond  Company,  2004).    However,  on  average,  diamonds  from 
 Ellendale 9 are larger (0.23 ct per stone) compared to those from Ellendale 4 (0.12 ct per 
 stone).  In addition, Ellendale 9 contains significant numbers of yellow stones resulting in 
 a larger proportion of gem-quality stones and a higher price per carat (557.5 A$mill for 
 Ellendale 9 and 297 A$mill).  Ellendale 4 diamonds are typically irregular and deformed 
 having  a  characteristic  brown  colour  and  lower  value.    A  distinct  chemical  difference 
 between  Ellendale  9  and  Ellendale  4  is  in  the  very  low  TiO2 (0-1  wt.  %)  of  chromite 
 xenocryst cores. This is interpreted to reflect the absence of metasomatic activity within 
 the mantle that is destructive to diamond (Ramsay, 1992). 
 The unit between the last Tuff and the first Magmatic Phase is an olivine lamproite with 
 volcaniclastic and magmatic characteristics.  This transitional phase contains no clasts or 
 lapilli  but  contains  high  olivine  content  and  low  phlogopite  phenocrysts  content.    The 
 transitional  phase  resembles  a  chilled  margin  of  magmatic  material.    The  transitional 
 phases have high microdiamond concentrations.  
 The compositions of xenocrysts from magmatic lamproite are  similar to those from the 
 last  tuffaceous  and  transitional  phase.    They  are  also  interpreted  to  have  been  derived 
 from a deep garnet-peridotite mantle, with the implication that a diamondiferous source 
 region  was  sampled.    However,  the  relatively  rare  diamonds  recovered  from  magmatic 
 lamproite  are  typically  frosted  and  display  corrosion  pitting,  providing  evidence  for 
 extensive  resorption  of diamonds in  the  source  magma.   In  addition, the  enrichment of 
 , and depletions of Cr2O3 and MgO, evident within the rims of chromite xenocrysts 
 are  interpreted to reflect  slow  magma  ascent  and/or  cooling  at  the  surface,  providing  a

39.text: The proposed diamond recovery method is design to recover all stones and eliminate

text:
remove coatings from harder grains, which include diamonds.  Milling techniques were 
 customised to suite the specific mineralogical properties of concentrates derived from 
 different lamproite lithologies i.e. limonite in tuffaceous and barite in magmatic 
 lamproite.  This method should ensure recovery of all diamonds from concentrate. 
 Concentrates that expose a significant number of light grains and solid limonite, the TBE 
 and magnetic separations are applied to remove these components from concentrates.  
 Final diamond recovery was done by hand sorting for coarse fractions and picking under 
 the microscope for finer fractions (-3mm).  After picking diamonds are weighed and +0.5 
 carat stones are counted before submitting for final diamond cleaning. Cleaned stones are 
 sized with DTC sieves and each size is weighed and diamonds are counted. For stones 
 smaller than 6DTC (-2.16mm) the average weight of 200 stones is used to calculate the 
 final number of diamonds.   
 The proposed diamond recovery method is design to recover all stones and eliminate
